reviewText:
Sherlock Holmes Classics Triple Feature

These movies were adapted from the Sherlock Holmes stories written by A. Conan Doyle from 1887 to 1890s. These stories have lessons as part of their entertainment. Doyle was interested in criminology and used true crimes as inspiration for these stories. Human nature (greed) continues. These movies are not copies of the original stories (are always worth reading), but used parts and adapted them to modern times. They are worth watching as entertainment and about the culture of the era. Read the individual reviews for more information, each movie uses a different actor for Holmes.

Murder at the Baskervilles [1937] is about the murder of a horse trainer and the loss of Silver Blaze. Did the dog bark in the night? Holmes recovers the lost horse and the murderer. Arthur Wontner plays Holmes.

A Study in Scarlet [1933] is about a dead man found in a locked railway carriage. The police send for Sherlock Holmes. Then there is another murder. Reginald Owen plays Holmes.

Dressed to Kill [1946] is about stolen music boxes. One has an engraved plate that can be used to print counterfeit 5 notes that cant be distinguished from genuine 5 notes! Can Sherlock Holmes recover the plates and catch the criminals? Basil Rathbone plays Holmes.
This DVD is everything that I had envisioned.
Three great classic Sherlock Holmes adaptations (not Conan Doye's) that are fun to watch. A great price and a excellent addition to any Sherlock Holmes collection.

I am a Sherlock Holmes fan , of this triple set of Holmes , Only one was what I could call Watchable & that was Dressed To Kill , Murder at the Baskervilles  with Arthur Wotner  as Holmes and A Study In Scarlet with Reginald Owen as Holmes , Were just terrible! , neither one was watchable & the sound is awful! , When ( If Ever ) Are they going to Restore the Sherlock Holmes Films Of Arther Wontner Or Reginald Owen ?? , I for one would gladly pay a premium price for their Sherlock Holm Films restored .  William Croce
